revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Amanita vaginata qtl1.jpg | image_width = 235px | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | subclassis = [[Hymenomycete]]s | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Amanitaceae]] | genus = ''[[Amanita]]'' | species = '''''A. vaginata''''' | binomial = ''Amanita vaginata'' | binomial_authority = (Bull.) Lam. (1783) | synonyms = ''Amanitopsis vaginata''
''Vaginata plumbea'' }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Amanita vaginata | whichGills = free | capShape = umbonate | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=volva | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=white | howEdible=edible | howEdible2=caution }} {{stack end}} '''''Amanita vaginata''''', commonly known as the '''grisette''', is an edible [[mushroom]] in the [[Amanitaceae]] family of fungi. Unlike many other ''Amanita'' mushrooms, ''A. vaginata'' lacks a ring on the stem. The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is gray or brownish, {{convert|5|to|10|cm|in|1}} in diameter, and has furrows around the edge that duplicate the gill pattern underneath. It has a widespread distribution in North America, and is thought to be part of a [[species complex]] that includes other similar-looking Amanitas. == Description == The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|3|to|10|cm|in|1}} in diameter and gray to grayish-brown in color; initially the cap is oval, then as it matures it becomes progressively conical, convex, and eventually flattened, sometimes with a small umbo (a rounded elevation in the center of the cap).{{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=Mushrooms Demystified: a Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, Calif |year=1986 |page=288 |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=n3rVpkZII8IC&pg=PA288&dq=amanita+vaginata&lr= Google Books] The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are white, free (not attached to the stem) to narrowly attached, moderately crowded together, and sometimes have a grayish tint; the lamellulae (small gills that run from the edge of the cap towards the stem) are truncate.{{cite book |author=Jenkins DB. |title=''Amanita'' of North America |publisher=Mad River Press |location=Eureka, Calif |year=1986 |page=71 |isbn=0-916422-55-0}} The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white and thin, and does not change color upon bruising or injury. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|8|to|22|cm|in}} long and {{convert|1|to|2|cm|in|1}} thick. Unlike many other Amanitas with stems that are swollen at the base (bulbous), the thickness of the ''A. vaginata'' stem is roughly the same at both ends. The stem surface is covered with a finely powdered bloom (pruinose), especially near the top; faint longitudinal lines may be seen. The base of the stem is enclosed in a loose, sack-like [[volva (mycology)|volva]] that may discolor grayish or reddish brown. The [[spore print]] is white. The variant ''A. vaginata'' var. ''alba'' is pure white, and has a volva that is either absent, or not constricted around the base of the stem.{{cite web |url=http://www.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/vagialba.html |title=''Amanita vaginata'' var. ''alba'' Gillet|author=Tulloss R |work= |accessdate=2009-07-30}} [[Image:AmanitaVaginata2.jpg|thumb|left]] === Microscopic features === The [[basidiospore|spores]] are roughly spherical, 8–12 μm in diameter, thin-walled, and [[nonamyloid]] (that is, not absorbing iodine stain in [[Melzer's reagent]]). The pileipellis (cap cuticle) is composed of filamentous interwoven [[hypha]]e, 2–7 μm diameter, gelatinized. The spore-bearing cells, the [[basidia]], are 36–52 by 4–13 μm, 4–sterigmate, without [[clamp connection|clamps]]. The volva is largely made of filamentous hyphae, 2–8 μm diameter, inflated cells broadly elliptic, elliptical, fusiform, to clavate, 40–85 by 10–35 μm, mostly terminal. The stem [[trama (mycology)|tissue]] is made up of filamentous hyphae with diameters of 2–6 μm; the inflated cells are terminal, club-shaped, longitudinally oriented, with dimensions of up to 289 by 31 μm. === Similar species === The tawny grisette (''[[Amanita fulva]]'') was once thought to be a variety of ''A. vaginata''.{{cite book |author=Russell B. |title=Field Guide to Wild Mushrooms of Pennsylvania and the Mid-Atlantic |publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |location=University Park |year=2006 |page=67 |isbn=0-271-02891-2}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=vLgjr5p0XFkC&pg=PA66&dq=amanita+vaginata Google Books] In North America, ''A. vaginata'' is considered to be part of a [[species complex]], that includes ''A. constricta'', ''A. pachycolea'' and ''A. protecta''.{{cite web |url=http://www.mykoweb.com/CAF/species/Amanita_vaginata.html |title=California Fungi: ''Amanita vaginata'' |vauthors=Wood M, Stevens S |publisher=MykoWeb|work= |accessdate=2009-07-30}} == Edibility == Although not poisonous, most authors advise against consumption due to the possibility of mistaking other poisonous species of ''Amanita'' for it.{{cite book |author1=Healy RA |author2=Huffman DR. |author3=Tiffany LH |author4=Knaphaus G. |title=Mushrooms and Other Fungi of the Midcontinental United States (Bur Oak Guide) |publisher=University of Iowa Press |location=Iowa City |year=2008 |page=55 |isbn=1-58729-627-6}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=tl2fVAHuej4C&pg=PA55&dq=amanita+vaginata&lr= Google Books]{{cite book |author=Hall IR. |title=Edible and Poisonous Mushrooms of the World |publisher=Timber Press |location=Portland, Or |year=2003 |pages= |isbn=0-88192-586-1 |oclc= |doi= }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=yqHA_M7BVRcC&pg=PA136&dq=amanita+vaginata Google Books]{{cite web|url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5563.asp|author=Phillips R|publisher=Rogers Plants Ltd.|title=Rogers Mushrooms | Mushroom Pictures & Mushroom Reference|accessdate=2009-07-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518043020/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5563.asp|archive-date=2008-05-18|url-status=dead}} A guide noted that the species is usually regarded as edible but there are also record of intoxication because of the species.{{cite book |author=Chang Shu-ting and Mao Xiaolan |title=Hong Kong Mushrooms |publisher=The Chinese University Press |location=Sha Tin, N.T., Hong Kong |year=1995 |pages=103 |isbn=962-201-626-X |oclc= |doi= }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=sAl8uFm8zHgC&lpg=PR49&ots=Ol2dNWYcfG&hl=en&pg=PA95 Google Books] One field guide notes that cows enjoy eating this mushroom. == Habitat and distribution == A [[mycorrhizal]] species, ''Amanita vaginata'' grows singly or numerous in both [[coniferous]] and [[hardwood]] forests. It has also been noted to occur frequently in grassy areas at the edge of forests, unkempt lawns, and suburban area where the ground has been recently disturbed.{{cite web |url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/amanita_vaginata.html |title=''Amanita vaginata'' (MushroomExpert.Com) |author=Kuo M|work= |accessdate=2009-07-30}} A widely distributed and common species, it fruits from the spring to the fall.{{cite book |vauthors=Miller HR, Miller OK |title=North American Mushrooms: a Field Guide to Edible and Inedible Fungi |publisher=Falcon Guide |location=Guilford, Conn |year=2006 |page=32 |isbn=0-7627-3109-5 |oclc= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zjvXkLpqsEgC&pg=PA32&dq=amanita+vaginata&lr=}} This species is widely distributed in North America. It is also found in the [[Azores]],{{cite journal |doi= 10.2307/4117263 |author1= Dennis, R. W. G |author2= Reid, D. A|year=1977 |author3= Spooner, B |title=The Fungi of the Azores |jstor= 4117263 |journal=Kew Bulletin |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages=85–136}} Australia,{{cite journal |doi= 10.2307/4113925 |author= Dennis, R. W. G. |year=1955 |title=New or Interesting Queensland Agaricales |journal=Kew Bulletin |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages= 107–110 |jstor= 4113925}} and Scotland.{{cite journal |doi= 10.2307/4113927 |author= Dennis, R. W. G |year= 1955 |title=The Larger Fungi in the North-West Highlands of Scotland |journal=Kew Bulletin |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=111–126 |jstor= 4113927}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110611050449/http://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/SynSpecies.asp?RecordID=114685 Index Fungorum] Synonyms * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133511/http://www.mushroomhobby.com/Gallery/Amanita/Amanita%20vaginata/index.htm Pictures and description] {{Amanitas}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q913459}} [[Category:Amanita|vaginata]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi of Australia]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]]
